author: By Remy Tumin and Sarah Hughes
title: George Floyd, Indianapolis, Spring Migration: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Main Line From the Heart
description: Andrea Carla Michaels loves the theme of this puzzle she created because, in a way, this is her life.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — You know how a random order like “Don’t press the red button” makes you itch to press that button immediately, no matter what dire consequence awaits? Well, whatever you do, please don’t read the Constructor Notes first. Don’t do it. Do. Not. Scroll Down. To. The. Notes. Period!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Fauci says he expects a decision Friday on whether the U.S. can resume using Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine.
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci said that he expected experts meeting at the end of the week to recommend “some sort of either warning or restriction.”
content: A decision about whether to resume administering the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine should come this Friday, when an expert panel that is advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is scheduled to meet, according to Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious disease expert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Banish Anxiety About Your Post-Lockdown Looks
description: The coronavirus changed so much about our lives, including, for many of us, our bodies. It’s OK.
content: Re-entry into pre-social distancing life is going to be such a joy. Re-entry into nonstretchy pants? Maybe not so much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: 12 Years 6 Months 25 Days: A Long Journey Back to the Majors
description: Sean Kazmar Jr., who pinch-hit for Atlanta on Saturday, had been in the minors since a brief call-up in 2008.
content: During the Atlanta Braves’ 13-4 loss to the Chicago Cubs at Wrigley Field on Saturday, infielder Sean Kazmar Jr. entered the game in the fifth inning as a pinch-hitter, saw four pitches and grounded into a double play. The three-minute appearance may not seem like much, but it meant the world to Kazmar and his family. It was Kazmar’s first major league game since Sept. 23, 2008 — a span of 4,589 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: After ‘Green Rush,’ Canada’s Legal Pot Suppliers Are Stumbling
description: Most marijuana producers in Canada are still reporting staggering losses two and a half years after legalization.
content: EXETER, Ontario — The mayor of the largely rural community of South Huron, Ontario, was looking forward to an employment boom when a marijuana producer used its soaring stock value to buy an enormous greenhouse on the edge of the municipality’s largest town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: A Bobcat Attacks, and a Husband Swings Into Action
description: Kristi Wade credits her husband, Happy Wade, with saving her life when a rabid bobcat attacked her in their North Carolina driveway.
content: Just before the bobcat attacked, the quiet subdivision where Happy and Kristi Wade live in Burgaw, N.C., was the very picture of suburban tranquillity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Joe Coscarelli
title: Black Rob, Rapper Known for His Hit Single ‘Whoa!,’ Dies at 52
description: A star for Bad Boy Records after the Notorious B.I.G.’s death, the rapper had a husky, seen-it-all voice even as a young man.
content: Robert Ross, the rapper known as Black Rob, whose husky, seen-it-all voice powered turn-of-the-millennium hits like “Whoa!” and “Can I Live” for Bad Boy Records, died on Saturday at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta. He was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: 2 Killed in Driverless Tesla Car Crash, Officials Say
description: “No one was driving the vehicle” when the car crashed and burst into flames, killing two men, a constable said.
content: Two men were killed in Texas after a Tesla they were in crashed on Saturday and caught fire with neither of the men behind the wheel, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Train Crash in Egypt Kills at Least 11
description: In a country known for poorly maintained equipment and mismanagement, a deadly accident north of Cairo adds to the trauma.
content: A passenger train derailed Sunday north of Cairo, killing at least 11 people and injuring scores more, the Egyptian authorities said. It was the latest of several deadly rail accidents to hit the country in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Hana de Goeij
title: Czechs Blame 2014 Blasts at Ammunition Depots on Elite Russian Spy Unit
description: The unit has also been implicated in the 2018 nerve agent attack in Salisbury, England, on Sergei Skripal, a former Russian spy, and his daughter.
content: The Czech Republic on Saturday blamed a series of mysterious 2014 explosions at Czech ammunition depots on an elite unit of Russia’s military intelligence service — a group that Britain has linked to a 2018 attack with a nerve agent on a former Russian spy in Salisbury, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Gustavo Dudamel Hasn’t Conducted Much Opera. That’s OK.
description: This classical superstar, just named as the Paris Opera’s next music director, isn’t the first maestro to jump to the theater.
content: The conductor Gustavo Dudamel has accomplished so much in his blazing career that it’s easy to forget he’s only 40. The music world has wondered for a while what his future would hold beyond the Los Angeles Philharmonic, a hotbed of adventurousness where he has been the musical leader since 2009. Major orchestras around the world have pursued him. Anything seemed possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: California Beach Seized in 1924 From a Black Family Could Be Returned
description: Nearly a century ago, the city of Manhattan Beach shuttered a resort that belonged to Willa and Charles Bruce. Though the county is trying to give the land back, the city has declined to apologize.
content: Nearly a century after a Southern California city shuttered a beach resort owned by a Black couple, the city, county and state are still reckoning over how to right past wrongs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: In the Roaring Twenties, Ads Make a Comeback
description: Subscriptions may be the rage, but businesses of all sorts are pouring money into advertising — digital most of all.
content: If you wanted to sound smart at a media business conference or sell your start-up over the last couple of years, you’d talk about the rise of digital subscriptions. Netflix and Spotify led the way in getting consumers to pay every month for their content, and The New York Times, The Washington Post and many others followed. By last week, everyone was hawking media subscriptions, from the owners of the SpongeBob SquarePants TV show ($5.99 a month) to the staid newswire Reuters ($35) to my friend Isaac who wanders aimlessly around New York ($7).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Build the Whole World With Your Hands (and Some Newspaper)
description: Creating a light-up globe from recycled materials is a good reminder of Earth’s beauty.
content: With the 51st anniversary of Earth Day approaching, many people will be celebrating the planet and focusing on what they can do to protect it. One way to remind yourself of Earth’s beauty is to make a light-up globe — from recycled newspaper, of course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Wilczek
title: Revisiting the Unusual Celebrity of Stephen Hawking
description: In “Hawking Hawking,” Charles Seife offers a portrait of the famous theoretical physicist and tries to unpack his place in popular culture.
content: HAWKING HAWKINGThe Selling of a Scientific CelebrityBy Charles Seife
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Fans Wait on Yankees to Show Up, but One Player Won’t Be Back
description: Jay Bruce, a recent arrival, announced his retirement, and the Yankees fell to 5-10, with problems that seem deeper than their struggles with Tampa Bay.
content: The Yankees lost again on Sunday to Tampa Bay, 4-2, a drearily routine result in an oddly lopsided rivalry. The Rays pulled their usual pitching voodoo, with an opener drafted in the 45th round and a closer with no career saves. The pitcher who worked most of the game has one of the slowest fastballs in the sport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sinn Fein Leader Apologizes for 1979 Killing of Prince Philip’s Uncle
description: Mary Lou McDonald, leader of the party that was once the political wing of the paramilitary Irish Republican Army, said she was sorry for its assassination of Louis Mountbatten.
content: LONDON — Seeking to salve an old wound at a time of sorrow for Britain’s royal family, the political leader of the Irish republican movement apologized on Sunday for the 1979 assassination of Louis Mountbatten, an uncle of Prince Philip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel, a world leader in vaccinations, lifts its outdoor mask mandate.
description: Daily new coronavirus infections in the country have fallen from a peak of 10,000 in January to around 100 on some recent days.
content: JERUSALEM — Buoyed by its recent success in combating the coronavirus, Israel lifted its outdoor mask mandate on Sunday, while schools fully reopened for the first time since September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Alex Jones’s Podcasting Hecklers Face Their Foil’s Downward Slide
description: Dan Friesen and Jordan Holmes turned their Infowars-skewering podcast into a business. In the post-Trump era, they’re documenting Mr. Jones’s reckoning.
content: CHICAGO — Last year, Alex Jones supplied conspiratorial content to the leader of the free world. This month, he was shamed by a nun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chencho Dema and Mike Ives
title: How the Tiny Kingdom of Bhutan Out-Vaccinated Most of the World
description: The Himalayan nation has given more than 60 percent of its people a shot. Some villages were reached by helicopter, and health workers hiked through ice and snow.
content: THIMPHU, Bhutan — The Lunana area of Bhutan is remote even by the standards of an isolated Himalayan kingdom: It covers an area about twice the size of New York City, borders far western China, includes glacial lakes and some of the world’s highest peaks, and is inaccessible by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: My Second Phase of Adulthood
description: How I’m changing my perspective on life.
content: This weekend I attended my second funeral in about six months. The first was my oldest brother’s. The second was for the mother of a college friend. Neither death was caused by the pandemic, but took place during it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: A Window Into a Changed America
description: In a National desk project, people across the country describe, in their own words, how the pandemic has transformed the way they live, work and think.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: From boardroom to bedroom: New York’s empty office buildings and hotels may be ripe for conversion.
description: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.
content: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Deadly Run-Ins With the Police Show No Pause
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 18, 2021.
content: “It’s just another example of a nothing offense escalated to lethality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Isabella Kwai
title: Shooting at Bar Near Kenosha, Wis., Leaves at Least 3 Dead
description: A suspect was located, the authorities said. Last year, a police shooting in Kenosha was followed by protests and the killings of two demonstrators.
content: Three people were killed and three more were hospitalized after a shooting at a bar early Sunday in Somers, Wis., near Kenosha, the latest instance of gun violence in a nation where such bloodshed has grown wearyingly commonplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Take the day to plan ahead and make a Mississippi Roast or fish cakes with herbs and chiles. Both will set you up for the days that follow.
content: Good morning. My colleague Margaux Laskey introduced me to Mississippi Roast (above). I wrote about the dish for The Times a short while later and, five years on, I still hear from people who make it monthly, sometimes as written and sometimes with gravy packets, sometimes with pork and often with venison. It’s the sort of flavor bomb that makes for a terrific dinner and great sandwiches with the leftovers on a following day. I think of it as a near-perfect Sunday supper, the kind that can simmer away all afternoon in a slow cooker or above a low flame on the stove, while you watch sports or read or prepare things for the freezer ahead of nights when you know you’re not going to want to start dinner from scratch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Outrage About European Super League Is Muffled by Our Cheers
description: A breakaway league would remake European soccer to benefit a few rich teams, but we will watch it anyway.
content: Real Madrid’s players pumped fists and exchanged hugs. A scoreless tie at Liverpool on Wednesday night had assured that the Spanish club had taken what it saw as its rightful place in the semifinals of the Champions League. All of a sudden, a 14th European Cup title hung tantalizingly close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Caro
title: Taking Over Victory Gardens to Make a ‘Theater for All’
description: Ken-Matt Martin, the esteemed Chicago theater’s first Black artistic director, is going in with his eyes open.
content: CHICAGO — Ken-Matt Martin, the incoming artistic director of Victory Gardens Theater here, said he never has revealed this publicly before, but he has a Sankofa bird tattooed on his back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: CBS News Will Try to Reinvent Itself, Again
description: In an interview as she prepares to step down as news division head, Susan Zirinsky said, “I feel I have given my entire soul into rebuilding this organization.”
content: In May 2020, a few months after “CBS Evening News” relocated from its longtime Manhattan home to Washington — a move that perplexed some producers and cost millions — the third-ranked newscast finally seemed to be finding a groove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: Despite Tensions, U.S. and China Agree to Work Together on Climate Change
description: The two countries said they would treat global warming “with the seriousness and urgency that it demands.”
content: SEOUL — The United States and China have said they will fight climate change “with the seriousness and urgency that it demands” by stepping up efforts to reduce carbon emissions, a rare demonstration of cooperation amid escalating tensions over a raft of other issues.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Voices Carry’
description: What will it take to get the choir of Washington’s Skagit Valley — and the rest of the world’s choral musicians — back together again?
content: The Skagit Valley choir last sang together on the evening of March 10, 2020. This rehearsal, it would turn out, was one of the first documented superspreader events of the pandemic. Of the 61 choristers who attended practice that night, 53 developed coronavirus symptoms. Two later died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Aleksei Navalny’s Health in Prison Is Dire, His Doctors Say
description: Doctors said recent blood tests indicated that the Russian opposition leader, who is nearly three weeks into a hunger strike, was at risk of heart failure and “could die at any moment.”
content: MOSCOW — The personal doctors of Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned Russian opposition leader, sharply escalated their warnings over the weekend about his health failing from a hunger strike, the lingering effects of an attempted poisoning with a chemical weapon and what they said was ill treatment in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jacob deGrom Fans Nine in a Row as Mets Split Doubleheader
description: The Mets’ ace fell one short of Tom Seaver’s major league record in a win over the Rockies. The Yankees dropped to an A.L.-worst record of 5-9.
content: DENVER — Jacob deGrom struck out nine straight batters against Colorado on Saturday, falling one shy of matching Tom Seaver’s major league record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Bake Bread and Hang Out With Whales
description: This week, tune in to a drag-queen story hour, learn about equity in the cannabis industry with Snoop Dogg or listen to a conversation with the journalist Don Lemon.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: She’s 18 and developed blood clots in her brain after a J&J vaccine. Here’s what happened.
description: An 18-year-old woman was stricken with severe headaches, vomiting, seizures, confusion and weakness in one arm early this month, strokelike symptoms that doctors at a Nevada hospital were shocked to see in someone so young.
content: An 18-year-old woman was stricken with severe headaches, vomiting, seizures, confusion and weakness in one arm early this month, strokelike symptoms that doctors at a Nevada hospital were shocked to see in someone so young.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: What Joe Biden and I Saw After the U.S. Invaded Afghanistan
description: Back when we visited in 2002, there was hope that America could help make the country better.
content: I was not surprised that Joe Biden decided to finally pull the plug on the U.S. presence in Afghanistan. Back in 2002 it was reasonable to hope that our invasion there to topple Osama bin Laden and his Taliban allies could be extended to help make that country a more stable, tolerant and decent place for its citizens — and less likely to host jihadist groups. But it was also reasonable to fear from the start that trying to graft a Western political culture onto such a deeply tribalized, male-dominated and Islamic fundamentalist culture like Afghanistan’s was a fool’s errand, especially when you factored in how much neighboring Pakistan never wanted us to succeed because it could wrench Afghanistan from Pakistan’s cultural and geopolitical orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 19, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Aleksei Navalny “could die at any moment,” his personal doctors say.
content: Aleksei Navalny, the imprisoned Russian opposition leader who survived an attempted poisoning and is now in the third week of a hunger strike, “could die at any moment,” his personal doctors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: A Different Way of Thinking About Cancel Culture
description: Social media companies and other organizations are looking out for themselves.
content: In March, Alexi McCammond, the newly hired editor of Teen Vogue, resigned following backlash over offensive tweets she’d sent a decade ago, beginning when she was 17. In January, Will Wilkinson lost his job as vice president for research at the center-right Niskanen Center for a satirical tweet about Republicans who wanted to hang Mike Pence. (Wilkinson was also suspended from his role as a Times Opinion contributor.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Top European Soccer Teams Form Breakaway League
description: Real Madrid, Manchester United, Liverpool and Juventus are among the dozen founding members of a league that would upend the sport’s structures and economics.
content: LONDON — A dozen of the world’s richest and most storied soccer clubs on Sunday announced that they had formed a breakaway European club competition that would, if it comes to fruition, upend the structures, economics and relationships that have bound global soccer for nearly a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: ‘The Free World’ Explains How Culture Heated Up During the Cold War
description: Louis Menand’s new book about art and thought in the postwar years features a very large cast, including George Orwell, James Baldwin, Susan Sontag and the Beatles.
content: In the spring of 1999, Louis Menand taught a class called “Art and Thought of the 1960s” at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. He assigned Malcolm X, Joan Didion, “Portnoy’s Complaint.” Toward the end of the semester, he told his students he was thinking of writing a book about the ’60s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Colorado health officials warn of a new surge as counties loosen virus restrictions.
description: Health officials say rising case counts are fueled in part by more contagious coronavirus variants, particularly B.1.1.7, the variant first found in Britain.
content: Health officials in Colorado are warning about another wave of infections as new coronavirus cases in the state jump to levels not seen since January and as counties start to loosen virus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: What Snoop Dogg’s Success Says About the Book Industry
description: Will the shifts brought on by the pandemic, favoring online retailers over bookstores and established authors over new ones, change publishing forever?
content: When bookstores across the United States closed last spring, Tyrrell Mahoney, the president of Chronicle Books, braced for disaster as she watched revenue plummet. Then, months into the crisis, Chronicle found an unlikely savior: the rapper Snoop Dogg and his two-year-old cookbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder, Michael H. Keller and Blacki Migliozzi
title: As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?
description: States have passed over 140 police oversight bills since the killing of George Floyd, increasing accountability and overhauling rules on the use of force. But the calls for change continue.
content: In February, Illinois enacted a law that rewrote many of the state’s rules of policing, and mandated that officers wear body cameras. In March, New York City moved to make it easier for citizens to sue officers. This month, the Maryland legislature — which decades ago became the first to adopt a Law Enforcement Officers’ Bill of Rights — became the first to do away with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis delivers his Sunday blessing to pilgrims in St. Peter’s Square for the first time in a month.
description: Throughout the pandemic, the pope has often delivered the weekly address, prayer and blessing from the apostolic library, with no public in attendance.
content: Pope Francis spoke to the faithful from his study overlooking St. Peter’s Square on Sunday, the first time he had done so in just over a month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘By the Time We Reached Main Street, I Had Lost Sight of Him ’
description: Commuting from Queens to Manhattan, neglected at the library and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: One America News Network Stays True to Trump
description: A recent OAN segment said there were “serious doubts about who’s actually president,” and another blamed “anti-Trump extremists” for the Capitol attack.
content: Months after the inauguration of President Biden, One America News Network, a right-wing cable news channel available in some 35 million households, has continued to broadcast segments questioning the validity of the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Airport vaccinations are just a flight away. To Alaska.
description: Alaska is the 22d state to announce plans to vaccinate nonresidents against the coronavirus.
content: To some, Alaska’s announcement that it would try to entice travelers by offering Covid-19 vaccinations at its airports might signal the state’s plucky resolve and determination to revive a tourism industry that has been devastated by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
title: The Oscars Are a Week Away, but How Many Will Watch?
description: TV ratings for awards shows have been in free fall, especially during the pandemic, and Hollywood doesn’t want the viewing public to toss its premier showcase into the entertainment dustbin.
content: LOS ANGELES — Neither intimate looks into stars’ living rooms nor scantily clad pop stars performing provocative hits have been able to stop audiences from tuning out award shows this year. The ratings for the Grammys were down by 53 percent. The Golden Globes plummeted by more than 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Aiming at variants, France will limit and quarantine travelers from Brazil, Argentina, Chile and South Africa.
description: As of April 24, entry into the country will be restricted, and those who qualify will be subject to a 10-day quarantine.
content: French authorities will tightly restrict who can travel to France from Brazil, Argentina, Chile and South Africa, and will impose a 10-day quarantine on those who do, in the hope of staving off worrisome coronavirus variants circulating in those countries, the government announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Week in Business: Let’s Go Shopping
description: Consumer spending is up — way up! — as Americans grow more optimistic about the economy.
content: Good morning. The economy is showing more signs of recovery — jobs are coming back, the stock market is up (again) and people are spending money. Here’s the latest in business and tech news for the week ahead. Stay safe out there. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Asian-American Artists, Now Activists, Push Back Against Hate
description: Newly spurred to action to combat bias, they generate subway posters, leverage social media, stage Zoom webinars. “Our community couldn’t take being invisible any longer,” one artist says.
content: Early in the pandemic, word started to travel among Asian-American artists: racist attacks were on the rise. Jamie Chan told a fellow artist, Kenneth Tam, about getting kicked out of an Uber pool ride by the driver who noticed her sniffling. Anicka Yi, an artist based in New York, called Christine Y. Kim, a curator at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, to talk about being spit at on a Manhattan street; Kim, in turn, recounted being accosted in a Whole Foods parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Marie Supikova, Survivor of Nazi Terror in Czech Village, Dies at 88
description: The men of Lidice, including her father, were massacred and the women, including her mother, sent to a concentration camp. She later testified at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials.
content: Marie Supikova, who, after surviving the Nazis’ destruction of her Czech village and being forced to live with a German family, testified about the horrors at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials when she was 15, died on March 22 in Prague. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fatima Faizi and Najim Rahim
title: Afghan Women Fear the Worst, Whether War or Peace Lies Ahead
description: Whatever happens once the United States withdraws will not bode well for Afghan women. But even the gains made for them over the last 20 years have often been fleeting.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Farzana Ahmadi watched as a neighbor in her village in northern Afghanistan was flogged by Taliban fighters last month. The crime: Her face was uncovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: Prepare Your Patio for the Season
description: Sprucing up for spring includes giving your lawn furniture the cleaning it deserves.
content: The weather is turning the corner, and that means one thing for certain: It’s patio season. Before you resurrect the outdoor space of your dreams, though, give your patio furniture the spring cleaning it deserves. Here’s how to get your furniture ready.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Go Ahead. Take a Nap.
description: Struggling at work? Daily naps may be the key to peak productivity
content: Struggling at work? Daily naps may be the key to peak productivity
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Cubicle Never Looked So Good
description: What we lose when we have to work from home.
content: What we lose when we have to work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Defund Facial Recognition
description: I’m a second-generation Black activist, and I’m tired of being spied on by the police.
content: I’m a second-generation Black activist, and I’m tired of being spied on by the police.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Covid in the Future
description: David Leonhardt’s popular morning briefing, exclusively for NYT Audio.
content: David Leonhardt’s popular morning briefing, exclusively for NYT Audio.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the Heck are NFTs? Let’s Ask Beeple.
description: On Sway, Kara Swisher asks the artist about whether his work is actually worth $69 million, and whether non-fungible tokens are the next new asset class, or all hype.
content: On Sway, Kara Swisher asks the artist about whether his work is actually worth $69 million, and whether non-fungible tokens are the next new asset class, or all hype.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cubicle Please!
description: Working from home has its perks, but some groups suffer from big drawbacks.
content: Working from home has its perks, but some groups suffer from big drawbacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mika Gröndahl, Tariro Mzezewa, Or Fleisher and Jeremy White
title: How Safe Are You From Covid When You Fly?
description: As vaccines become widely available and restrictions are eased, millions of people are flying again, raising questions about just how safe it is now to board a flight.
content: As vaccines become widely available and restrictions are eased, millions of people are flying again, raising questions about just how safe it is now to board a flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Listen to a Changing Planet, Through These 5 Climate Podcasts
description: Understanding the climate crisis is tough. Let these audio storytellers help you understand the problems, and potential solutions.
content: Giving climate change a worthy amount of attention  can seem a daunting task. The scope of the problem is colossal; the obstacles to equitable solutions myriad. Yet we know the time for ignoring global warming has long passed. This Earth Day (Thursday), make a resolution to learn more about our collective planetary problems, along with possible solutions. in the form of audio.  There’s a sea of informative climate podcasts out there — in fact, a grass-roots movement has issued an open letter challenging Apple Podcasts to add a climate category to its many classifications — but these five audio journeys of climate storytelling are all fabulous places to start.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Climate Threat Posed by Plastics
description: “Clearly, Amazon is not the only culprit in this sorry mess,” a reader writes. “But it is the largest and the one whose positive actions would have the greatest impact.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 18, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 18, 2021.
content: An article on Page 15 this weekend about play reading groups describes incorrectly the type of work that donors to the Playwrights Realm could pay to act in. They could commission new plays or pay a smaller fee to act in a previously written play.
source.name: The New York Times
